content: The Act titled "Home Health Documentation and Program Improvement Act of 2017" requires information to satisfy documentation of Medicare eligibility for home health services. The Act "Home Health Documentation and Program Improvement Act of 2017" amends sections of the Social Security Act to include documentation requirements for physician certification and recertification of home health services. The Social Security Act is amended to include documentation requirements for physician certification and recertification of home health services, effective January 1, 2018. The Secretary will use documentation from the home health agency's medical record as supporting material for certification and recertification. SEC. 3. VOLUNTARY SETTLEMENT OF HOME HEALTH CLAIMS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a settlement process for home health claims within one year of the Act's enactment. Home health agencies with eligible appeals can choose to settle with the Secretary. Settlements must be reached in accordance with specific procedures and cover all claims by the agency. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a settlement process for home health claims within one year of the Act's enactment. Home health agencies with eligible appeals can choose to settle with the Secretary. Settlements must cover all claims by the agency and suspend administrative appeals during the process. The Secretary will determine the aggregate amount to be paid to the agency for all claims under appeal. The Secretary will establish a settlement process for home health claims, allowing agencies to settle eligible appeals. The settlement amount will be calculated based on a percentage, similar to the Medicare & Medicaid Services hospital appeals settlement. The settlement process for home health claims involves calculating the total sum of individual claim amounts for each agency. As part of the settlement, agencies must forego the right to appeal administratively under specific sections of the Social Security Act. The settlement process for home health claims involves calculating total claim amounts for each agency. Agencies must waive their right to appeal administratively or judicially under specific sections of the Social Security Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will coordinate with law enforcement to prevent settlement of cases involving fraud. This section does not create an entitlement to enter the settlement process. Eligible administrative appeal is defined as an appeal in this context. An "eligible administrative appeal" refers to an appeal related to home health services provided between January 1, 2011, and January 1, 2015, that were deemed reasonable and necessary under the Social Security Act. The appeal must be timely filed and consistent with specific sections of the Act.
